These activities include the production of [renewable](/wiki/Renewable_energy), [nuclear](/wiki/Nuclear_power), and [fossil fuel](/wiki/Fossil_fuel) derived sources of energy, and for the [recovery and reuse of energy](/wiki/Waste_heat) that would otherwise be wasted. [Energy conservation](/wiki/Energy_conservation) and [efficiency measures](/wiki/Efficient_energy_use) reduce the demand for energy development, and can have benefits to society with improvements to [environmental issues](/wiki/Environmental_issue). Societies use energy for transportation, manufacturing, illumination, heating and air conditioning, and communication, for industrial, commercial, and domestic purposes. Energy resources may be classified as primary resources, where the resource can be used in substantially its original form, or as secondary resources, where the energy source must be converted into a more conveniently usable form. Non-renewable resources are significantly depleted by human use, whereas renewable resources are produced by ongoing processes that can sustain indefinite human exploitation. Thousands of people are employed in the [energy industry](/wiki/Energy_industry). The conventional industry comprises the [petroleum industry](/wiki/Petroleum_industry), the natural gas industry, the [electrical power industry](/wiki/Electrical_power_industry), and the [nuclear industry](/wiki/Nuclear_industry). New energy industries include the [renewable energy industry](/wiki/Renewable_energy_industry), comprising alternative and sustainable manufacture, distribution, and sale of [alternative fuels](/wiki/Alternative_fuel). Classification of resources[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Energy_development&action=edit§ion=1)] Energy resources may be classified as primary resources, suitable for end use without conversion to another form, or secondary resources, where the usable form of energy required substantial conversion from a primary source. Examples of primary energy resources are [wind power](/wiki/Wind_power), [solar power](/wiki/Solar_power), wood fuel, fossil fuels such as coal, oil and natural gas, and uranium. Secondary resources are those such as electricity, [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen_economy), or other synthetic fuels. Another important classification is based on the time required to regenerate an energy resource. "Renewable" resources are those that recover their capacity in a time significant by human needs. Examples are hydroelectric power or wind power, when the natural phenomena that are the primary source of energy are ongoing and not depleted by human demands. Non-renewable resources are those that are significantly depleted by human usage and that will not recover their potential significantly during human lifetimes. An example of a non-renewable energy source is coal, which does not form naturally at a rate that would support human use. Fossil fuels[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Energy_development&action=edit§ion=2)] Fossil fuel (primary non-renewable fossil) sources burn [coal](/wiki/Coal) or [hydrocarbon](/wiki/Hydrocarbon) fuels, which are the remains of the decomposition of plants and animals. There are three main types of fossil fuels: coal, [petroleum](/wiki/Petroleum), and [natural gas](/wiki/Natural_gas). Another fossil fuel, [liquefied petroleum gas](/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas) (LPG), is principally derived from the production of natural gas. Heat from burning fossil fuel is used either directly for space heating and process heating, or converted to mechanical energy for vehicles, [industrial processes](/wiki/Industrial_process), or [electrical power generation](/wiki/Electrical_power_generation). These fossil fuels are part of the [carbon cycle](/wiki/Carbon_cycle) and allow solar energy stored in the fuel to be released. The use of fossil fuels in the 18th and 19th century set the stage for the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution). Fossil fuels make up the bulk of the world's current [primary energy](/wiki/Primary_energy) sources. In 2005, 81% of the world's energy needs was met from fossil sources. Liquid fuels derived from petroleum deliver much usable energy per unit of weight or volume, which is advantageous when compared with lower [energy density](/wiki/Energy_density) sources such as [batteries](/wiki/Battery_(electricity)). Fossil fuels are currently economical for decentralized energy use. [Energy dependence](/wiki/Energy_dependence) on imported fossil fuels creates [energy dependent countries. [[98]](#cite_note-Solar_energy_ie11-98) Biofuels[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Energy_development&action=edit§ion=13)] A biofuel is a [fuel](/wiki/Fuel) that contains energy from geologically recent [carbon fixation](/wiki/Carbon_fixation). These fuels are produced from [living organisms](/wiki/Living_organisms). Examples of this [carbon fixation](/wiki/Carbon_fixation) occur in [plants](/wiki/Plants) and [microalgae](/wiki/Microalgae). These fuels are made by a [biomass](/wiki/Biomass) conversion (biomass refers to recently living organisms, most often referring to [plants](/wiki/Plants) or plant-derived materials). This biomass can be converted to convenient energy containing substances in three different ways: thermal conversion, chemical conversion, and biochemical conversion. This biomass conversion can result in fuel in [solid](/wiki/Solid), [liquid](/wiki/Liquid), or [gas](/wiki/Gas) form. This new biomass can be used for biofuels. Biofuels have increased in popularity because of rising [oil prices](/wiki/Oil_prices) and the need for [energy security](/wiki/Energy_security). [Bioethanol](/wiki/Bioethanol) is an [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol_(chemistry)) made by [fermentation](/wiki/Ethanol_fermentation), mostly from [carbohydrates](/wiki/Carbohydrate) produced in [sugar](/wiki/Sugar) [starch](/wiki/Starch) crops such as [corn](/wiki/Maize) or [sugarcane](/wiki/Sugarcane). [Cellulosic biomass](/wiki/Cellulose), derived from non-food sources, such as trees and grasses, is also being developed as a [feedstock](/wiki/Feedstock) for ethanol production. Ethanol can be used as a fuel for vehicles in its pure form, but it is usually used as a [gasoline](/wiki/Gasoline) [additive](/wiki/Fuel_additive) to increase octane and improve vehicle emissions. Bioethanol is widely used in the [USA](/wiki/Biofuel_in_the_United_States) and in [Brazil](/wiki/Ethanol_fuel_in_Brazil). Current plant design does not provide for converting the [lignin](/wiki/Lignin) portion of plant raw materials to fuel components by fermentation. [Biodiesel](/wiki/Biodiesel) is made from [vegetable oils](/wiki/Vegetable_oil) and [animal fats](/wiki/Animal_fat). Biodiesel can be used as a fuel for vehicles in its pure form, but it is usually used as a [diesel](/wiki/Diesel_fuel) additive to reduce levels of particulates, [carbon monoxide](/wiki/Carbon_monoxide), and [hydrocarbons](/wiki/Hydrocarbon) from diesel-powered vehicles. Biodiesel is produced from oils or fats using [transesterification](/wiki/Transesterification) and is the most common biofuel in Europe. [Ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol), [methanol](/wiki/Methanol) (both controversial) or hydrogen for [fuel cells](/wiki/Fuel_cells) can be had from these technologies and used to generate electricity. Enabling technologies[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Energy_development&action=edit§ion=38)] [Heat pumps](/wiki/Heat_pumps) and [Thermal energy storage](/wiki/Thermal_energy_storage) are classes of technologies that can enable the utilization of [renewable energy](/wiki/Renewable_energy) sources that would otherwise be inaccessible due to a temperature that is too low for utilization or a time lag between when the energy is available and when it is needed. While enhancing the temperature of available renewable thermal energy, heat pumps have the additional property of leveraging electrical power (or in some cases mechanical or thermal power) by using it to extract additional energy from a low quality source (such as seawater, lake water, the ground, the air, or [waste heat](/wiki/Waste_heat) from a process). Thermal storage technologies allow heat or cold to be stored for periods of time ranging from hours or overnight to [interseasonal](/wiki/Seasonal_thermal_energy_storage), and can involve storage of [sensible energy](/wiki/Sensible_heat) (i.e. by changing the temperature of a medium) or [latent energy](/wiki/Latent_energy) (i.e. through phase changes of a medium, such between water and slush or ice). Short-term thermal storages can be used for peak-shaving in district heating or electrical distribution systems. Kinds of renewable or alternative energy sources that can be enabled include natural energy (e.g. collected via solar-thermal collectors, or dry cooling towers used to collect winter's cold), waste energy (e.g. from HVAC equipment, industrial processes or power plants), or surplus energy (e.g. as seasonally from hydropower projects or intermittently from wind farms). The [Drake Landing Solar Community](/wiki/Drake_Landing_Solar_Community) (Alberta, Canada) is illustrative. [borehole thermal energy storage](/wiki/Seasonal_thermal_energy_storage) allows the community to get 97% of its year-round heat from solar collectors on the garage roofs, which most of the heat collected in summer. [[155]](#cite_note-155) [[156]](#cite_note-156) Types of storages for sensible energy include insulated tanks, borehole clusters in substrates ranging from gravel to bedrock, deep aquifers, or shallow lined pits that are insulated on top. Some types of storage are capable of storing heat or cold [between opposing seasons](/wiki/Seasonal_thermal_energy_storage) (particularly if very large), and some storage applications require inclusion of a [heat pump](/wiki/Heat_pumps). Latent heat is typically stored in ice tanks or what are called [phase-change materials](/wiki/Phase-change_material) (PCMs).
